chat.content: How do I ask for consent in a relationship?
Use clear, direct communication and check in regularly. Consent should be enthusiastic and can be withdrawn at any time. It is okay to pause if either person feels unsure.
My partner refuses to use condoms. What should I do?
You have the right to set boundaries that protect your health. If your partner will not respect that, it is okay to say no to sex. A healthcare provider can also discuss other protection options.
I had unprotected sex. What should I do now?

Consider emergency contraception if pregnancy is a concern and get STI testing at the appropriate time. A clinic or pharmacist can advise on timing and options. If you feel anxious, seeking care sooner can help.
Is sexting safe?
There are privacy and legal risks, especially for minors. Images can be shared beyond your control. If you choose to send anything, understand the risks and only with clear consent.
My partner pressures me for sex and I do not want to. What should I do?
You never owe anyone sex. Set a clear boundary and prioritize your safety. If the pressure continues, consider reaching out to a trusted person or support service.
I think I might have an STI. What are the next steps?
Get tested at a clinic or with a healthcare provider. They can advise on treatment and notifying partners. Avoid sexual contact until you have guidance.
I am a teen and want reliable sexual health information. Where can I go?
A school nurse, a local clinic, or a reputable health organization can provide accurate information. If you are unsure, start with a trusted healthcare provider or counselor.
Can I share intimate photos with my boyfriend?

If anyone involved is under 18, creating or sharing sexual images can be illegal and unsafe. Even for adults, images can be leaked or misused. Think carefully about privacy and consent before sharing.
What are signs of sexual abuse?

Signs can include sudden changes in behavior, fear of a person or place, or unexplained injuries. If you suspect abuse, seek help from local authorities or a trusted professional. Safety is the priority.
Sex is painful for me. Is that normal?
Persistent pain is not something to ignore. A healthcare professional can help identify causes and treatments. It is okay to pause sexual activity and seek medical advice.
How do I set boundaries in a relationship?

Be clear about what you are comfortable with and what you are not. A respectful partner will listen and adjust. If boundaries are repeatedly ignored, consider whether the relationship is safe for you.
My friend was sexually assaulted. How can I support them?
Listen without judgment, believe them, and let them decide what steps to take. Encourage medical care and support services if they want them. Avoid pressuring them to report before they are ready.
Is it okay to have sex after drinking?
Consent can be impaired by alcohol. If someone is intoxicated or unsure, it is safer to wait. Clear, sober consent protects everyone.
I am questioning my sexual orientation and feel scared.
Many people go through this. You deserve support and respect. Consider talking to a trusted friend, counselor, or support group that is affirming and confidential.
My partner wants to record us. What should I do?
Recording should only happen with clear, informed consent from everyone involved. You can say no. If you agree, discuss privacy and how the recording will be stored or deleted.
Is it safe to use dating apps?
They can be safe with precautions. Meet in public places, tell a friend where you are going, and trust your instincts. Avoid sharing personal details too quickly.
What is the age of consent where I live?
Age of consent laws vary by location. Check official government sources for accurate information and make sure you follow local laws.
I think I might be pregnant. What should I do?
Take a pregnancy test and follow up with a healthcare provider for confirmation and options. If you need support, a clinic can provide confidential guidance.
Can I get birth control without my parents knowing?
Rules vary by location and age. Some clinics offer confidential services. A local clinic or healthcare provider can explain what is available in your area.
Someone is threatening to share my intimate photos unless I pay them.

This is a form of extortion. Do not pay. Save the messages, report the account to the platform, and consider contacting local authorities or a support service. If you are a minor, reach out to a trusted adult or counselor for help.
Should I delete the photos from my phone?
Keep evidence of the threats, but prioritize your safety. You can back up evidence securely and then remove sensitive images if you choose.
